Line 214: Line 214:
[[Mark Shuttleworth]] indicated at least eight million people used Ubuntu by the end of 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redherring.com/Home/20497|title=Linux: Ubuntu Founder On Desktop Innovation|accessdate=2008-06-13}}</ref> resulting in a large up-spring of non-Canonical websites. These websites include general help sites (Easy Ubuntu Linux<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.easy-ubuntu-linux.com | title=Easy Ubuntu Linux | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>), dedicated [[Blog|weblogs]] (Ubuntu Gazette<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.techlifeweb.com/linux/ubuntu.html | title = Ubuntu Gazette | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>), niche websites (Ubuntu Women<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ubuntu-women.org/ | title=Ubuntu Women | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>) and online publications (Full Circle<ref>{{cite web | url=http://fullcirclemagazine.org/ | title=Full Circle | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.frostwire.com/?id=downloads| title=FrostWire.com - Official Website - Free BitTorrent/Gnutella Client - No subscriptions; just download and install| publisher=www.frostwire.com| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.getdeb.net/| title=GetDeb - Software you want| publisher=www.getdeb.net| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.skype.com/download/skype/linux/choose/| title=Download Skype for Linux| publisher=www.skype.com| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
[[Mark Shuttleworth]] indicated at least eight million people used Ubuntu by the end of 2006,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redherring.com/Home/20497|title=Linux: Ubuntu Founder On Desktop Innovation|accessdate=2008-06-13}}</ref> resulting in a large up-spring of non-Canonical websites. These websites include general help sites (Easy Ubuntu Linux<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.easy-ubuntu-linux.com | title=Easy Ubuntu Linux | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>), dedicated [[Blog|weblogs]] (Ubuntu Gazette<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.techlifeweb.com/linux/ubuntu.html | title = Ubuntu Gazette | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>), niche websites (Ubuntu Women<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ubuntu-women.org/ | title=Ubuntu Women | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>) and online publications (Full Circle<ref>{{cite web | url=http://fullcirclemagazine.org/ | title=Full Circle | accessdate=2008-01-07}}</ref>).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.frostwire.com/?id=downloads| title=FrostWire.com - Official Website - Free BitTorrent/Gnutella Client - No subscriptions; just download and install| publisher=www.frostwire.com| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.getdeb.net/| title=GetDeb - Software you want| publisher=www.getdeb.net| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.skype.com/download/skype/linux/choose/| title=Download Skype for Linux| publisher=www.skype.com| accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
â
Ubuntu has also received negative assessments. ''[[Ars Technica]]'' reviewed the initial release of Ubuntu 8.04 and concluded that while it was a clear improvement over Ubuntu 7.10, some flaws significantly detracted from the quality of the user experience.<ref name="Heron has landed">{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/reviews/os/hardy-heron-review.ars|title= The heron has landed: a review of Ubuntu 8.04|accessdate= 2008-06-08|author= Ryan Paul|last= Paul|first= Ryan|date= 2008-05-07|work= [[Ars Technica]]|publisher= CondÃ© Nast Publications}}</ref> Specifically, ''Ars Technica'' felt that [[Transmission (BitTorrent client)|Transmission]] (a BitTorrent client) was too simple for BitTorrent power users, that the default search system [[Tracker (desktop search software)|Tracker]] was inferior to [[Beagle (software)|Beagle]] and that the [[PulseAudio]] configuration that shipped was buggy<ref name="Heron has landed" /> (a view shared by Pulseaudio creator Lennart Poettering, who states, "''Ubuntu didn't exactly do a stellar job <nowiki>[adopting PulseAudio]</nowiki>. They didn't do their homework''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://0pointer.de/blog/projects/jeffrey-stedfast.html|title=PulseAudio FUD|author=Lennart Poettering}}</ref>). ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'' criticized the lack of an integrated desktop effects manager, although this did not prevent them from naming Ubuntu the "best all-around Linux distribution available today".<ref name="PCW Ubu V Fed">{{cite web|url= http://www.pcworld.com/article/146400/desktop_linux_faceoff_ubuntu_804_vs_fedora_9.html|title= Desktop Linux Face-Off: Ubuntu 8.04 vs. Fedora 9|accessdate= 2008-08-19|author= Robert Strohmeyer|last= Strohmeyer|first= Robert|date= [[2008-06-02]]|year= 2008|month= June|work= [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|publisher= [[IDG|International Data Group]]}}</ref> ''ChannelWeb'' criticized the [[Wubi (Ubuntu)|Wubi]] installer, noting that it hung after the installation was complete.<ref name="CW Wins Laurels">{{cite web|url= http://www.crn.com/software/207401927;jsessionid=DRRXPFKYTBXVMQSNDLOSKH0CJUNN2JVN?pgno=2|title= Review: Why Ubuntu 'Hardy Heron' Wins Laurels|accessdate= 2008-06-12|author= Fahmida Y. Rashid|last= Rashid|first= Fahmida Y.|date= [[2008-04-24]]|year= 2008|month= April|work= ChannelWeb|publisher= United Business Media LLC}}</ref> ''ChannelWeb'' also noted that while they were able to connect to Microsoft [[Active Directory|Active Directories]], the process was not seamless.<ref name="CW Wins Laurels" /> In their preview of Ubuntu 8.04 ''[[InfoWorld]]'' stated that they felt Brasero's CD/DVD burning was lackluster as compared to similar pay-to-use programs available for Windows or [[Mac OS X]].<ref name="IW UB804beta">{{cite web|url= http://www.infoworld.com/article/08/03/24/13TC-ubuntu-beta_1.html|title= Ubuntu 8.04 beta: an agile upgrade: The latest build of everyone's favorite open source desktop OS features better performance, Active Directory integration, and seamless installation from Windows |accessdate= 2008-06-12|author= Neil McAllister|last= McAllister|first= Neil |date= [[2008-03-24]]|work= [[InfoWorld]]|publisher= [[IDG|International Data Group]]}}</ref>
+
Ubuntu has also received negative assessments. ''[[Ars Technica]]'' reviewed the initial release of Ubuntu 8.04 and concluded that while it was a clear improvement over Ubuntu 7.10, some flaws significantly detracted from the quality of the user experience.<ref name="Heron has landed">{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/reviews/os/hardy-heron-review.ars|title= The heron has landed: a review of Ubuntu 8.04|accessdate= 2008-06-08|author= Ryan Paul|last= Paul|first= Ryan|date= 2008-05-07|work= [[Ars Technica]]|publisher= CondÃ© Nast Publications}}</ref> Specifically, ''Ars Technica'' felt that [[Transmission (BitTorrent client)|Transmission]] (a BitTorrent client) was too simple for BitTorrent power users, that the default search system [[Tracker (desktop search software)|Tracker]] was inferior to [[Beagle (software)|Beagle]] and that the [[PulseAudio]] configuration that shipped was buggy<ref name="Heron has landed" /> (a view shared by Pulseaudio creator Lennart Poettering, who states, "''Ubuntu didn't exactly do a stellar job <nowiki>[adopting PulseAudio]</nowiki>. They didn't do their homework''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://0pointer.de/blog/projects/jeffrey-stedfast.html|title=PulseAudio FUD|author=Lennart Poettering}}</ref>). ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'' criticized the lack of an integrated desktop effects manager, although this did not prevent them from naming Ubuntu the "best all-around Linux distribution available today".<ref name="PCW Ubu V Fed">{{cite web|url= http://www.pcworld.com/article/146400/desktop_linux_faceoff_ubuntu_804_vs_fedora_9.html|title= Desktop Linux Face-Off: Ubuntu 8.04 vs. Fedora 9|accessdate= 2008-08-19|author= Robert Strohmeyer|last= Strohmeyer|first= Robert|date= [[2008-06-02]]|year= 2008|month= June|work= [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|publisher= [[IDG|International Data Group]]}}</ref> ''ChannelWeb'' criticized the [[Wubi (installer)|Wubi]] installer, noting that it hung after the installation was complete.<ref name="CW Wins Laurels">{{cite web|url= http://www.crn.com/software/207401927;jsessionid=DRRXPFKYTBXVMQSNDLOSKH0CJUNN2JVN?pgno=2|title= Review: Why Ubuntu 'Hardy Heron' Wins Laurels|accessdate= 2008-06-12|author= Fahmida Y. Rashid|last= Rashid|first= Fahmida Y.|date= [[2008-04-24]]|year= 2008|month= April|work= ChannelWeb|publisher= United Business Media LLC}}</ref> ''ChannelWeb'' also noted that while they were able to connect to Microsoft [[Active Directory|Active Directories]], the process was not seamless.<ref name="CW Wins Laurels" /> In their preview of Ubuntu 8.04 ''[[InfoWorld]]'' stated that they felt Brasero's CD/DVD burning was lackluster as compared to similar pay-to-use programs available for Windows or [[Mac OS X]].<ref name="IW UB804beta">{{cite web|url= http://www.infoworld.com/article/08/03/24/13TC-ubuntu-beta_1.html|title= Ubuntu 8.04 beta: an agile upgrade: The latest build of everyone's favorite open source desktop OS features better performance, Active Directory integration, and seamless installation from Windows |accessdate= 2008-06-12|author= Neil McAllister|last= McAllister|first= Neil |date= [[2008-03-24]]|work= [[InfoWorld]]|publisher= [[IDG|International Data Group]]}}</ref>
